title: Commuter chaos but worth it to drive forward the Northern Powerhouse?
text:
To find out more watch ITV Party People tonight at 10:40pm
Greater Manchester is now the second most congested area in the country - with each commuter spending an average 52 hours last year stuck in traffic. That's the equivalent of more than six working days.
In a study conducted by by transport information firm Inrix, Manchester came second only to London for time wasted in traffic, where each driver spent 12 working days or 96 hours spent in traffic last year.
The Government's investing £13 billion in transport to help create the Northern Power House but could the current congestion crisis have been avoided if it had been mapped out better and do the arguments for High Speed 2 add up?
Rail passengers caught up in the commuter crush Credit: GTV We've followed one commuter's train journey from Bolton to Manchester city centre.
Jamie Shawcross pays £1,200 a year for rail travel but says he is late for work 4 days out of 5 because he simply cannot get on a train.
Play video In October 2014, the Government created a new body called Transport for the North made up of the northern city regions.
Its aim will be to work together with other authorities and stakeholders and allow the North to speak with one voice on the big decisions to benefit the region as a whole.
We spoke to TfN's newly appointed Chief Executive David Brown on how he hopes it will help the region "punch its weight economically"
Play video Chris Fletcher from Greater Manchester Chamber of Commerce talks timings and how he hopes the current building projects will "create a transport system fit for purpose".
